text:
February 6 at 10:40 AM Follow @JamesHohmann Martellus Bennett, with his daughter, answers questions after the Super Bowl in Houston last night. He said he will boycott the White House ceremony to recognize the team's championship because he objects to Donald Trump. (Chuck Burton/AP) With Breanne Deppisch
THE BIG IDEA: The permanent campaign pervades more deeply into our lives than ever before, so it should come as no surprise that we could not escape politics during last night‚Äôs Super Bowl -- before, during or after the game.
Martellus Bennett of the New England Patriots told reporters following his team‚Äôs stunning win that he will not travel to the White House for the traditional celebration as long as it‚Äôs occupied by Donald Trump. The star tight end has been sharply critical of the president, including his immigration ban last week:
Surprised the president dude didn't ban celebrating Chinese New Year in America!!
‚Äî Martellus Bennett (@MartysaurusRex) January 29, 2017 Meanwhile, Trump and his own fans celebrated the victory as if it was one of their own. The president reiterated to Bill O‚ÄôReilly during an interview before the game that he is good friends with New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft, coach Bill Belichick and quarterback Tom Brady. Brady has distanced himself to varying degrees from his friend since a ‚ÄúMake America Great Again‚Äù hat was spotted in his locker two years ago.
Trump cheered on the Patriots during a watch party in Florida, but he left a little before 9 p.m. , when the Atlanta Falcons were up 28-3. Before the game, POTUS had predicted a Patriots victory by eight points. It‚Äôs unclear if he caught the final half hour, but he quickly tweeted congratulations afterward:
What an amazing comeback and win by the Patriots. Tom Brady, Bob Kraft and Coach B are total winners. Wow!
‚Äî Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 6, 2017 So did diehard Patriots fan (and White House press secretary) Sean Spicer:
Best. Game. Ever. Congrats @Patriots #SuperBowl #SuperBowl2017 #SuperBowlLI
‚Äî Sean Spicer (@seanspicer) February 6, 2017 Tom Brady celebrates with wife Gisele Bundchen and daughter Vivian Brady after the game. (Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images) IF YOU MISSED THE GAME -- Great takes on deadline from four of our sports reporters:
-- In a rally for the ages, quarterback Tom Brady scored the game‚Äôs final 31 points to defeat the Atlanta Falcons, 34-28, in overtime. ‚ÄúThe Patriots trailed 21-0 in the first half, 28-3 in the third quarter and 28-9 entering the fourth quarter,‚Äù Mask Maske files from Houston . ‚ÄúYet they secured their fifth Super Bowl triumph in seven appearances in the big game with Bill Belichick as their coach and Brady as their quarterback.‚Äù
-- ‚Äú Brady [who is 39] played the greatest game of football the sport has seen ,‚Äù Adam Kilgore writes. ‚ÄúNot the most perfect, nor the most artistic, nor even the most excellent. Just the greatest. He led the Patriots back from a 28-3 deficit on a stage that had never seen anything better than a 10-point comeback. He passed for 466 yards, a Super Bowl record, and completed 43 of 62 passes. He led a 91-yard drive touchdown in the final four minutes, capped with a two-point conversion.‚Äù
-- ‚Äú Consider it the greatest comeback and the greatest choke in 51 years of this game ,‚Äù Jerry Brewer says. ‚ÄúLike like most games that shift dramatically, it was a combination of Patriots greatness and Falcons mistakes and perplexing decisions that contributed to the drama. In the end, though, you will most remember the Patriots‚Äô extraordinary resolve. ... You will remember the Patriots, complimented often for their brains and ingenuity and ruthlessness, showcasing another trait: guts.‚Äù
-- ‚Äú Deflategate ended with Super Bowl LI, and Roger Goodell heard the boos to prove it ,‚Äù adds Cindy Boren. ‚ÄúThis championship was, Kraft said, ‚Äòunequivocally the sweetest.‚Äô And Goodell, who has avoided going to New England for two full regular seasons now, was drowned out by boos as he spoke and handed the trophy to Kraft. After taking the Lombardi Trophy, Kraft said: ‚ÄòA lot has transpired over the last two years and I don‚Äôt think that needs any explanation.‚Äô Goodell will get the chance to have a public moment with Brady and Belichick on Monday morning, when he presents Brady with the MVP trophy.‚Äù
THE ADS‚Äî
At least eight of the commercials during the Super Bowl, which cost $5 million per 30 seconds to air, had a political message:
Airbnb said last weekend that it will give free housing to refugees and any others not allowed into the United States because of Trump‚Äôs travel ban. During the game, the home-sharing site showed faces of people from many different ethnic backgrounds. ‚Äú We all belong,‚Äù the ad said. ‚ÄúThe world is more beautiful the more you accept‚Äù:
A family-owned company called 84 Lumber produced a commercial that showed a Mexican mother and daughter trying to immigrate into the United States. Their original version showed the pair arriving at an imposing border wall. But Fox rejected that as too controversial, the company said, so the ad was re-cut to show a less imposing barbed-wire fence. It ends with the mother and daughter holding hands, with a link to the company‚Äôs website.
‚ÄúIgnoring the border wall and the conversation around immigration that‚Äôs taking place in the media and at every kitchen table in America just didn‚Äôt seem right,‚Äù Rob Shapiro, who works at the ad agency that helped 84 Lumber come up with the ad, told Marissa Payne. ‚ÄúIf everyone else is trying to avoid controversy, isn‚Äôt that the time when brands should take a stand for what they believe in?‚Äù
See the original, rejected ad here:
Audi highlighted the lack of equal pay for women in a spot with the tagline, ‚ÄúProgress is for everyone.‚Äù A male narrator poses the question: ‚ÄúWhat do I tell my daughter? Do I tell her that her grandpa is worth more than her grandma? That her dad is worth more than her mom?‚Äù As his daughter wins a road race, he wonders how he can stop her from ‚Äúbeing valued less than every man she ever meets.‚Äù Cindy Boren observes , ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a smart ad, given that women wield incredible influence in household purchases, and it was directed by a woman.‚Äù Watch:
Coca-Cola re-aired an ad just before kickoff with people singing ‚ÄúAmerica the Beautiful‚Äù in different languages:
An ad from the hair care brand "It's a 10" advertised men‚Äôs products by alluding to Trump: ‚ÄúAmerica, we're in for four years of awful hair,‚Äù the narrator said. ‚ÄúSo it's up to you to do your part by making up for it with great hair. ‚Ä¶ Do your part. ... Let's make sure these next four years are ‚ÄòIt's a 10.‚Äô‚Äù
Cyprus Air used a bad Donald Trump impersonator to sell gas fireplaces in a spot that ran in the D.C. media market. ‚ÄúWashington is so cold. I thought Russia was cold,‚Äù the fake Trump says. He says Cyprus has a yuuuge sale:
Some ads were not intended to be political, but people couldn‚Äôt help see them that way in the context of the Trump presidency. An ad promoting ‚Äúavocados from Mexico‚Äù invariably prompted commentary about Trump‚Äôs proposed tariff to get our southern neighbor to pay for the wall:
An ad provided by the NFL portrayed football as something that unifies all Americans. ‚ÄúWe may have our differences, but recognize there's more that unites us,‚Äù Forest Whitaker narrated:
But the social media conversation surrounding many of the commercials underscored just how divided we have become as a nation in 2017. A Budweiser spot about the immigration story of its German founder, Adolphus Busch, opened with Busch being told, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt look like you‚Äôre from around here‚Äù:
The company claims the ad was in the works for nearly a year , long before the election, but it was unavoidably seen by both supporters and detractors as a critique of Trump‚Äôs nativism. A ‚ÄúBoycott Budweiser‚Äù movement trended online throughout the game:
#BOYCOTT @Budweiser . Political ads have no place being aired during #Superbowl #Americans want to protect our country! #BoycottBudweiser pic.twitter.com/TT9OvWMIE7
‚Äî President Trump (@SupportDonald) February 1, 2017 @budlight No thanks... it's time to #BoycottBudweiser . We don't need your beer, your opinions, and your illegal immigrants.
‚Äî MAGADauntlessDiamond (@diamondgirl2222) February 2, 2017 @Budweiser COULD have been inspring but you chose to go negative "You‚Äôre not wanted here‚Äù applies to your beer in my home #boycottbudweiser
‚Äî GWardHome (@gwardhome) February 1, 2017 Lady Gaga performs during the halftime show. (Matt Slocum/AP) THE HALFTIME SHOW:
Lady Gaga was not as politically explicit as many expected, but progressives heard the political overtones in her message. When she sang ‚ÄúThis land is made for you and me,‚Äù for example, Hillary Clinton tweeted:
I'm one of 100 million #SuperBowl fans that just went #Gaga for the Lady, & her message to all of us. https://t.co/8AoNqjwr1b
‚Äî Hillary Clinton (@HillaryClinton) February 6, 2017 WaPo pop music critic Chris Richards points out that Gaga‚Äôs performance was not as political as last year, when Beyonc√©‚Äô came onto the field surrounded by a squadron of dancers dressed in Black Panther garb. But she still went farther out on a limb than many artists have in past years : ‚ÄúShe marched into ‚ÄòBorn This Way,‚Äô a melodic celebration of ‚Äògay, straight, or bi, lesbian, transgender life.‚Äô ‚Ä¶ Instead of speaking out, Gaga asked a mild question, ‚ÄúHow are you doing tonight, Texas? America? World?‚Äù She already knew the answer ‚Äî not great. So she asked another one: ‚ÄòYou wanna feel good with us?‚Äô For a moment, it felt like she was finally inviting us to her kind of party ‚Äî one where the doors are open to weirdos, outcasts, freaks and geeks. But as energetic as she appeared up there, it still felt restrained.‚Äù
George H.W. Bush flips the coin, with wife Barbara. (Al Bello/Getty Images) EVEN THE PRE-GAME SHOW HAD SOME POLITICS:
-- Three members from the original cast of ‚ÄúHamilton,‚Äù the women who played the Schuyler sisters, put their own spin on the first verse of ‚ÄúAmerica the Beautiful.‚Äù They tweaked the penultimate line of the first verse by singing, ‚ÄúAnd crown thy good with brotherhood ‚Ä¶ and sisterhood‚Äù before finishing, ‚Äúfrom sea to shining sea!‚Äù
The creator of ‚ÄúHamilton‚Äù loved it:
AND SISTERHOOD. pic.twitter.com/2Zx8Sg9XmW
‚Äî Lin-Manuel Miranda (@Lin_Manuel) February 5, 2017 A huge smile broke out on Falcons Coach Dan Quinn‚Äôs face when he heard the ‚Äúsisterhood‚Äù line:
#SuperBowl #SchuylerSisters #AndSisterhood lol this coachs reaction was literally me pic.twitter.com/vsxw6EHTTT
‚Äî Jade Le Pape ü¶ã (@jlepape007) February 5, 2017 But Patriots coach Belichick didn‚Äôt appear to be as moved by the performance (though, to be fair, he never really smiles at anything):
the harshest transition ever pic.twitter.com/n20IkHAYmx
‚Äî Mike Tunison (@xmasape) February 5, 2017 Bush 41 received a standing ovation from the crowd as he was rolled in for the coin toss at the start of the game.
Meanwhile, this plane circled the stadium as fans went inside:
A plane circling NRG stadium in Houston, is flying a banner reading: "üá∫üá∏No One Is Above The Constitution." #SuperBowlSunday pic.twitter.com/qKMgQYXPTV
‚Äî Shaquille Brewster (@shaqbrewster) February 5, 2017 In an interview that aired ahead of the game on Fox, Trump announced that Mike Pence will be the point man on looking into his unsubstantiated claims that millions of people voted illegally in the presidential election. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to set up a commission ‚Ä¶ headed by ‚Ä¶ Pence, and we‚Äôre going to look at it very, very carefully,‚Äù the president told Bill O‚ÄôReilly.
The V.P. enjoyed the game from a skybox with former Secretary of State James Baker and Texas Gov. Greg Abbott:
Former Secretary of State James Baker sitting next to @mike_pence at #Superbowl . Would love to overhear their conversations tonight. pic.twitter.com/rLLknDaTgO
‚Äî Pam Konde (@SosKon_Policy) February 6, 2017 Photo of the Day: President @GeorgeHWBush , VP @mike_pence , SoS James Baker, and Gov. @GregAbbott_TX at #SuperBowl51 ! #txlege pic.twitter.com/uxYItCOhr7
‚Äî Michael Jenkins (@MikeJenkinsUSA) February 6, 2017 THE INEVITABLE 2016 COMPARISONS:
The statistical odds of a Patriots comeback were less than 1 percent for a chunk of the game. Afterward, it seemed like everyone on Twitter ‚Äì from Bill Maher to Donald Trump Jr. ‚Äì compared the result to Election Night. Scott Allen rounds up some fun examples :
In case you forgot... #SuperBowl #SuperBowlSunday pic.twitter.com/IrfJLAlV6G
‚Äî Donald Trump Jr. (@DonaldJTrumpJr) February 6, 2017 This is looking like Hillary all over again.
‚Äî Bill Maher (@billmaher) February 6, 2017 Wow. Just like the November election. Complete with Falcon fans celebrating their Super Bowl victory 30 min early.
‚Äî Michael Moore (@MMFlint) February 6, 2017 This game reminds me of something. I can't quite place it. pic.twitter.com/JAPkRLrePZ
‚Äî Chris Cillizza (@TheFix) February 6, 2017 I can't believe the guy with the foreign model wife and a sketchy history with the rules just won after being written off.
‚Äî Ben Shapiro (@benshapiro) February 6, 2017 The storied overwhelming favorite from a legacy of winning is poised to lose to a no name upstart... #2016 #dejavu #SuperBowl
‚Äî Annie Linskey (@AnnieLinskey) February 6, 2017 A joke about 2016, but with the Falcons playing the role of Hillary Clinton. Please RT
‚Äî Dave Weigel (@daveweigel) February 6, 2017 The Falcons never should have kept emails on a private server
‚Äî Tim Layden (@SITimLayden) February 6, 2017 -- Trump supporters celebrated the victory as a sign that the new president is making America great again:
@DonaldJTrumpJr Have you ever seen a single picture with SO MUCH WINNING? #MAGA https://t.co/VpWTa069nk pic.twitter.com/RkhxBbu2Rg
‚Äî The Will To Win (@TWTWsports) February 6, 2017 -- Boston is one of the country‚Äôs most liberal metropolitan areas, so Trump‚Äôs outspoken support for the team made some fans uneasy. A campaign caught on in the Bay State in which people pledged to give a certain amount of money to charities and groups that oppose Trump for every touchdown the Patriots scored. The idea was dreamed up by ‚ÄúLast Week Tonight‚Äù writer Josh Gondelman. ( Marissa Payne looks at how the cause went viral. )
Three people who participated:
Today I donated $50 towards my church's refugee aid fund in advance of the @Patriots win! #AGoodGame #SuperBowlSunday #StandUpToTrump pic.twitter.com/kD4DKeduE5
‚Äî Emily D. Price (@offbeatstomp) February 5, 2017 I'll be donating $10 for every Patriots TD and $5 for every Patriots FG to the @ACLU_Mass #AGoodGame https://t.co/btQiJq6cqo
‚Äî Apricot Bees (@ApricotBees) February 5, 2017 If you didn't craft something to keep track, did it even happen? #AGoodGame @joshgondelman pic.twitter.com/MqZkvcahpC
‚Äî Jenna (@JennaLCrowley) February 5, 2017 -- Regardless of how they feel about Trump, though, everyone in New England is cheering this morning:
In today‚Äôs Globe: Recapping #Patriots comeback, @Dan_Shaughnessy on historic night, more https://t.co/znAHXOpFcp pic.twitter.com/eYsQawjQHR
‚Äî The Boston Globe (@BostonGlobe) February 6, 2017 Today's Boston Herald Wrap pic.twitter.com/eCBcenfX8o
‚Äî Boston Herald (@bostonherald) February 6, 2017 -- Do you believe in miracles? A survey conducted on the eve of the game found that one quarter of Americans believe God plays a role in deciding the winner of the game. Meanwhile, nearly 50 percent of Americans said they think God rewards athletes who are more devout on game day.
Welcome to the Daily 202, PowerPost's morning newsletter.
With contributions from Elise Viebeck ( @eliseviebeck ).
Sign up to receive the newsletter.
WHILE YOU WERE SLEEPING:
TRUMP VS. THE COURTS, THE TECH INDUSTRY AND THE NATIONAL SECURITY COMPLEX:
-- A federal appeals court on Sunday declined to reinstate Trump‚Äôs travel ban, allowing those previously banned from coming to the United States at least another day to get here. Matt Zapotosky and Robert Barnes report : ‚ÄúThe decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit preserves a lower judge‚Äôs order to temporarily halt the ban ‚Äî and based on a schedule the court outlined, the stop will remain in place at least until sometime on Monday. The Justice Department said it would not elevate the dispute to the Supreme Court before that. What ultimately lies ahead likely is a weeks-long battle that will be waged in various courtrooms across the country."
-- A group of Silicon Valley tech giants ‚Äì including Apple, Facebook, Microsoft, Uber and 93 more firms ‚Äì will file a legal brief today opposing Trump‚Äôs travel ban. Elizabeth Dwoskin reports : ‚ÄúThe move represents a rare coordinated action across a broad swath of the industry and demonstrates the depth of animosity toward the Trump ban. The filing describes Trump‚Äôs ban as a ‚Äúseismic shift‚Äù toward discrimination that departs dramatically from principles that have governed U.S. immigration law for decades: "Long-term, this instability [caused by the executive order] will make it far more difficult and expensive for U.S. companies to hire the world‚Äôs best talent‚Äîand impede them from competing in the global marketplace.‚Äù
-- Former Secretaries of State John Kerry and Madeleine Albright, along with a host of other former top national security officials, including former Secretary of Defense/CIA director Leon Panetta, published a six-page declaration this morning that the White House order ‚Äúundermines‚Äù our national security and will ‚Äúendanger U.S. troops in the field.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe all agree that the United States faces real threats from terrorist networks and that vetting is necessary,‚Äù the distinguished elder statesmen say. ‚ÄúWe all are nevertheless unaware of any specific threat that would justify the travel ban‚Äô established by the executive order. Rather, they said they viewed it as one that ‚Äòultimately undermines the national security of the United States rather than making us safer. ‚Äù It will ‚Äúdisrupt key counterterrorism, foreign policy and national security partnerships,‚Äù they declare, and ‚Äúendanger intelligence sources in the field‚Äù by ‚Äúbreaching faith‚Äù with them. (Read Fred Barbash‚Äôs story. Read the full declaration here .)
-- Former CIA director Michael V. Hayden explains why Trump‚Äôs ban hurts American spies in countries affected by the order ‚Äì damaging critical relationships between case officers and human sources that help keep America safe. ‚ÄúSome will quibble ‚Ä¶ that this is a temporary ban (maybe) and exceptions can be made (possibly),‚Äù he writes in today‚Äôs Post. ‚ÄúBut ‚Ä¶ it doesn‚Äôt take paranoia to connect the action of the executive order with the hateful, anti-Islamic language of the campaign. In the Middle East, with its honor-based cultures, it‚Äôs easier to recruit someone we have been shooting at than it is to recruit someone whose society has been insulted." The simple idea of America didn‚Äôt hurt either: ‚Äú[One] station chief said that one of the fundamentals of his business was selling the dream. The Soviets ‚Äòhad a hard time with that. We had it easy. They didn‚Äôt necessarily want to go there, but it was a place they kept in their minds where they would be welcome.‚Äô‚Äù
-- A crush of people stranded in legal limbo are rushing to fly back into the United States while the temporary stay remains in effect, and vulnerable refugee families who had been scheduled to travel to America are living in fear and limbo. Louisa Loveluck and Zakaria Zakaria report : ‚ÄúLast month, the Tawouz family were told a new life in the U.S. was just days away. Last week, they learned they were no longer welcome. And by Saturday, they had no idea what to believe. ‚ÄòWe‚Äôve been hopeful, we‚Äôve been devastated. Now we just don‚Äôt know,‚Äô said Majid Tawouz, a father of five ‚Ä¶Their bags had been packed and were nearly bursting on the morning in late January when they learned they would not need them.‚Äù Now, an aid official says the U.N. will likely be expected to sort through already-vetted case files to identify the most vulnerable families for referral to another nation‚Äôs resettlement program. ‚ÄúFor Wajeeha, 11, the suspension meant an indefinite wait for hormone treatment that the family cannot afford in Turkey ‚Ä¶ For her younger brother, it meant longer until a doctor can explain why his bones have grown curved. Moments later, Wajeeha‚Äôs small voice echoed down the phone line. ‚ÄòI was so excited, but now I just feel sad,‚Äô she said. ‚ÄòBaba told me there aren‚Äôt planes for people like us anymore. Why don‚Äôt they want us?‚Äô‚Äù
The Syrian refugee Anas Modamani arrives for court today in his lawsuit against Facebook in Wurzburg, Germany. (Thomas Lohnes/Getty Images) GET SMART FAST: ‚Äã‚Äã
A Syrian refugee in Germany is suing Facebook after a selfie he snapped with Angela Merkel was seized upon by a number of ‚Äúfake news‚Äù sites that accused him of being a terrorist ‚Äì and posted doctored photos linking him to recent terror attacks in the country. The case will be heard in court today and is the latest attempt to hold Facebook accountable for the surge in fake news. ( Stephanie Kirchner and Anthony Faiola ) A Florida Uber driver was suspended after passengers recognized him as Terry Jones, the 65-year-old who made global headlines a few years back for organizing an ‚ÄúInternational Burn a Koran Day.‚Äù After being questioned by the ride-hailing company, Jones admitted to spreading his anti-Muslim message with passengers and to carrying a handgun in his vehicle. ( Faiz Siddiqui ) New York police have charged a man with second degree murder in the death of jogger Karina Vetrano, who was slain last August on a trail near her normally quiet town of Howard Beach . Authorities said they received more than 250 leads from the public before taking the suspect into custody this weekend. ( Amy B Wang and Sarah Larimer ) At least 100 people were killed in a string of avalanches and snowstorms that plagued Afghanistan this weekend, blocking key roads across the country and shuttering all scheduled flights from Kabul‚Äôs airport. Local reports said ‚Äúscores‚Äù of homes were destroyed or badly damaged in the deluge, which obstructed rescuers from sending aid to some of the most heavily-hit areas. ( Sayed Salahuddin ) The U.N. has removed longtime Afghan insurgent leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar from its sanctions list, after he put an end to nearly four decades of military campaigning by signing a peace deal with the Afghan government last year. He is expected to return to Kabul within weeks. ( Sayed Salahuddin ) Judge Neil Gorsuch meets with lawmakers on Capitol Hill. (Melina Mara/The Washington Post) POTUS MAKING CONFIRMATION HARDER FOR GORSUCH:
-- Trump continues to show little respect for the rule of law. He spent the weekend directly attacking Judge James L. Robart , who was appointed by George W. Bush to the federal bench and confirmed by the Senate unanimously. He wrote on Twitter: ‚ÄúJust cannot believe a judge would put our country in such peril. If something happens blame him and court system. People pouring in. Bad!‚Äù That came a day after he described Robart as a "so called judge."
-- The Twitter assault has motivated Democrats to challenge his Supreme Court nominee on an important but elusive issue: ‚ÄúIs [Neil] Gorsuch independent enough, to stand up to the president who picked him?‚Äù Robert Barnes previews: ‚ÄúIt is already clear that Trump‚Äôs broadsides against Robart, who put the president‚Äôs immigration order on hold, have placed Gorsuch in a difficult position. It‚Äôs a difficult situation [both] for Gorsuch and those shepherding his nomination. On the one hand, they want to energize the base by portraying Gorsuch as a solid conservative worthy of the late Justice Antonin Scalia‚Äôs place on the court. But at the same time, they must combat the view that he would be a rubber stamp for a president whose hard-charging style shows little patience for the separation of powers. Those who have studied Gorsuch‚Äôs record say he has shown a skepticism about government power but warn against weaving a philosophy from a series of unrelated votes."
-- More questions are emerging about Gorsuch‚Äôs reported volunteer work with the Harvard Prison Legal Assistance Project and the Harvard Defenders. The Wall Street Journal‚Äôs Beth Reinhard and Jess Bravin report : ‚ÄúHis affiliation with these volunteer programs ‚Ä¶ helped give Mr. Gorsuch‚Äôs deeply conservative r√©sum√© a personal touch, and the groups were highlighted in news reports about his nomination. But roughly three dozen students who participated in the two programs while Mr. Gorsuch was at Harvard Law School from 1988 to 1991 said they have no recollection of his involvement. Two people who broadly oversaw the students during this period said they had no memory of Judge Gorsuch‚Äôs involvement, a third one declined to say, and a fourth died in 1998. Other Harvard classmates and friends of Mr. Gorsuch say they have no recollection of him discussing either program . ‚ÄòIf he was active in PLAP I am sure I would remember him,‚Äô said Elizabeth Buckley Lewis, who attended Harvard at the same time as Gorsuch and said PLAP was her 'most meaningful' Harvard experience."
-- A fresh CNN/ORC poll finds Americans‚Äô first impressions of Gorsuch tilting positive, with 49 percent saying he should be confirmed. Meanwhile, 36 percent said he should be rejected, and 15 percent have ‚Äúno opinion.‚Äù And 49 percent of voters said Gorsuch‚Äôs ideological position is ‚Äúabout right‚Äù ‚Äì slightly less than the 56 percent who said so about Merrick Garland.
Trump holds up an executive action at the Pentagon. (Mandel Ngan/Getty) THE WHITE HOUSE IS TRYING TO GET ITS ACT TOGETHER:
-- The New York Times‚Äô Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman report how the bungled rollout of the travel ban, as well as a flurry of other miscues, have Trump rethinking the improvisational governing approach that mirrors his chaotic campaign style. ‚ÄúCloistered in the White House, he now has little access to his fans and supporters ‚Äî an important source of feedback and validation ‚Äî and feels increasingly pinched by the pressures of the job. ‚Ä¶ For a sense of what is happening outside, he watches cable, both at night and during the day ‚Äî too much in the eyes of some aides ‚Äî often offering a bitter play-by-play of critics like CNN‚Äôs Don Lemon. ... Until the past few days, Mr. Trump was telling his friends and advisers that he believed the opening stages of his presidency were going well . But his opinion has begun to change with a relentless parade of bad headlines.
"By then, the president, for whom chains of command and policy minutiae rarely meant much, was demanding that Mr. Priebus begin to implement a much more conventional White House protocol that had been taken for granted in previous administrations: From now on, Mr. Trump would be looped in on the drafting of executive orders much earlier in the process . Another change will be a new set of checks on the previously unfettered power enjoyed by Mr. Bannon and [Stephen Miller]. Additionally, Priebus has created a 10-point checklist for release of any new initiatives ‚Äì which include signoff from communications department and the White House staff secretary. ... One former staff member likened the aggressive approach of the first two weeks to D-Day, but said the president‚Äôs team had stormed the beaches without any plan for a longer war."
A one-paragraph distillation of Trump's governing style: The Times notes that the president is obsessed with his Oval Office d√©cor, and has asked staff to schedule as many events in the room as possible. ‚ÄúTo pass the time between meetings, Mr. Trump gives quick tours to visitors, highlighting little tweaks he has made after initially expecting he would have to pay for them himself. He will linger on the opulence of the newly hung golden drapes ‚Ä¶ For a man who sometimes has trouble concentrating on policy memos, Mr. Trump was delighted to page through a book that offered him 17 window covering options."
-- On the campaign trail, Trump vowed, ‚ÄúI alone can fix it.‚Äù But as he heads into his third full week in office, he is discovering even the most powerful job in the world has limits. Karen Tumulty and David Nakamura report: ‚ÄúRepublican allies in Congress are grumbling about not being consulted. Foreign leaders are refusing to buckle to his bluster. A rebellion is brewing within the emboldened federal bureaucracy. Meanwhile, his own aides are bickering and providing the news media a steady stream of leaks about palace intrigue. The establishment that he vowed to blow up is more potent in practice than it seemed when he was making it his political foil during an election season. Trump‚Äôs difficulties come partly from the constraints faced by all presidents in a system in which there are three branches of government ‚Ä¶ a far different environment from Trump‚Äôs previous career running a family-owned real estate and branding empire. The question now is whether Trump will adjust in the face of the institutional and political realities or continue to maintain his imperious posture.‚Äù
-- Why so many leaks from the Trump White House? Our Paul Farhi lays out a few different theories: "[Some] reporters say the leaks reflect a certain degree of chaos within the new administration, with factions warily circling one another. ‚ÄòI tend to think chaos begets chaos begets chaos, and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre seeing here,‚Äô said a reporter familiar with some of the senior players. But others see the leaks as whistleblowing ‚Äî an effort to expose Trump‚Äôs initiatives before they become policy. Of course, the leaks could also be trial balloons launched by the administration ‚Ä¶ Neither Trump nor his top officials have challenged the veracity of any of the major leaks.
